natural problem:
A sequence of integers is defined as follows: $a_i = i$ for $1 \le i \le 5,$ and
\[a_i = a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1} - 1\]for $i > 5.$  Evaluate $a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{2011} - \sum_{i = 1}^{2011} a_i^2.$
natural solution: For $i \ge 6,$ $a_i = a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1} - 1.$  So \begin{align} a_{i + 1} &= a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_i - 1 \\ &= (a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1}) a_i - 1 \\ &= (a_i + 1) a_i - 1 \\ &= a_i^2 + a_i - 1. \end{align}Then $a_i^2 = a_{i + 1} - a_i + 1,$ so

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = i"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i > 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = (PROD j : {1..i-1}. a j) - 1"
shows  "(PROD i : {1..2011}. a i) - (\<Sum>i = 1..2011. a i powr 2) = -1941"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A sequence of integers is defined as follows: $a_i = i$ for $1 \le i \le 5,$ and
\[a_i = a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1} - 1\]for $i > 5.$  Evaluate $a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{2011} - \sum_{i = 1}^{2011} a_i^2.$ The final Answer is -1941
 ### Proof
 For $i \ge 6,$ $a_i = a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1} - 1.$  So \begin{align} a_{i + 1} &= a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_i - 1 \\ &= (a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1}) a_i - 1 \\ &= (a_i + 1) a_i - 1 \\ &= a_i^2 + a_i - 1. \end{align}Then $a_i^2 = a_{i + 1} - a_i + 1,$ so
 \begin{align} a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{2011} - \sum_{i = 1}^{2011} a_i^2 &= a_{2012} + 1 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - \sum_{i = 6}^{2011} (a_{i + 1} - a_i + 1) \\ &= a_{2012} + 1 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - (a_{2012} - a_6 + 2006) \\
 &= a_6 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - 2005 \\ &= 119 - (1^2 + 2^2 + 3^2 + 4^2 + 5^2) - 2005 \\ &= \boxed{-1941}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = i"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i > 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = (PROD j : {1..i-1}. a j) - 1"
shows  "(PROD i : {1..2011}. a i) - (\<Sum>i = 1..2011. a i powr 2) = -1941"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider a sequence $a$ of natural numbers such that $a(i) = i$ for all $1 \leq i \leq 5$, and $a(i) = \prod_{j=1}^{i-1} a(j) - 1$ for all $i > 5$. What is the value of $\prod_{i=1}^{2011} a(i) - \sum_{i=1}^{2011} a(i)^2$? The final answer is $-1941$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = i"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i > 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = (PROD j: {1..i - 1}. a j) - 1"
shows  "(PROD i: {1..2011}. a i) - (\<Sum>i = 1..2011. (a i)^2) = -1941"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A sequence of integers is defined as follows: $a_i = i$ for $1 \le i \le 5,$ and
\[a_i = a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1} - 1\]for $i > 5.$  Evaluate $a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{2011} - \sum_{i = 1}^{2011} a_i^2.$ The final Answer is -1941
 ### Proof
 For $i \ge 6,$ $a_i = a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1} - 1.$  So \begin{align} a_{i + 1} &= a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_i - 1 \\ &= (a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1}) a_i - 1 \\ &= (a_i + 1) a_i - 1 \\ &= a_i^2 + a_i - 1. \end{align}Then $a_i^2 = a_{i + 1} - a_i + 1,$ so
 \begin{align} a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{2011} - \sum_{i = 1}^{2011} a_i^2 &= a_{2012} + 1 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - \sum_{i = 6}^{2011} (a_{i + 1} - a_i + 1) \\ &= a_{2012} + 1 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - (a_{2012} - a_6 + 2006) \\
 &= a_6 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - 2005 \\ &= 119 - (1^2 + 2^2 + 3^2 + 4^2 + 5^2) - 2005 \\ &= \boxed{-1941}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = i"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i > 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = (PROD j: {1..i - 1}. a j) - 1"
shows  "(PROD i: {1..2011}. a i) - (\<Sum>i = 1..2011. (a i)^2) = -1941"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: For a sequence $a$, it is given that $a(i) = i$ for $1 \leq i \leq 5$ and $a(i) = (a(1) \cdot a(2) \cdot \ldots \cdot a(i-1)) - 1$ for $i > 5$. What is the value of $(a(1) \cdot a(2) \cdot \ldots \cdot a(2011)) - (a(1)^2 + a(2)^2 + \ldots + a(2011)^2)$? The final answer is $-1941$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int" and prod :: "int \<Rightarrow> int" and sum :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = i"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. i > 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = prod(i - 1) - 1"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. prod n = (\<Prod> i = 1..n. a i)"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. sum n = (\<Sum> i = 1..n. a i ^ 2)"
shows  "prod 2011 - sum 2011 = -1941"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A sequence of integers is defined as follows: $a_i = i$ for $1 \le i \le 5,$ and
\[a_i = a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1} - 1\]for $i > 5.$  Evaluate $a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{2011} - \sum_{i = 1}^{2011} a_i^2.$ The final Answer is -1941
 ### Proof
 For $i \ge 6,$ $a_i = a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1} - 1.$  So \begin{align} a_{i + 1} &= a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_i - 1 \\ &= (a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1}) a_i - 1 \\ &= (a_i + 1) a_i - 1 \\ &= a_i^2 + a_i - 1. \end{align}Then $a_i^2 = a_{i + 1} - a_i + 1,$ so
 \begin{align} a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{2011} - \sum_{i = 1}^{2011} a_i^2 &= a_{2012} + 1 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - \sum_{i = 6}^{2011} (a_{i + 1} - a_i + 1) \\ &= a_{2012} + 1 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - (a_{2012} - a_6 + 2006) \\
 &= a_6 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - 2005 \\ &= 119 - (1^2 + 2^2 + 3^2 + 4^2 + 5^2) - 2005 \\ &= \boxed{-1941}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int" and prod :: "int \<Rightarrow> int" and sum :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = i"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. i > 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = prod(i - 1) - 1"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. prod n = (\<Prod> i = 1..n. a i)"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. sum n = (\<Sum> i = 1..n. a i ^ 2)"
shows  "prod 2011 - sum 2011 = -1941"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Consider a sequence of integers $a(i)$ such that for $1 \leq i \leq 5$, $a(i) = i$, and for $i > 5$, $a(i)$ equals the product of the previous $i-1$ terms in the sequence, minus 1. Now, consider two functions, prod and sum, such that prod(n) equals the product of the first n terms in the sequence, and sum(n) equals the sum of the squares of the first n terms in the sequence. What is the difference between prod(2011) and sum(2011)? The final answer is -1941.

 \begin{align} a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{2011} - \sum_{i = 1}^{2011} a_i^2 &= a_{2012} + 1 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - \sum_{i = 6}^{2011} (a_{i + 1} - a_i + 1) \\ &= a_{2012} + 1 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - (a_{2012} - a_6 + 2006) \\
 &= a_6 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - 2005 \\ &= 119 - (1^2 + 2^2 + 3^2 + 4^2 + 5^2) - 2005 \\ &= \boxed{-1941}. \end{align}

and h1 : "\<forall> i. i > 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = (prod a {1..i - 1}) - 1"
shows  "(prod a {1..2011}) - (sum (\<lambda>i. a i ^ 2) {1..2011}) = -1941"

(* ### Problem

\[a_i = a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1} - 1\]for $i > 5.$  Evaluate $a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{2011} - \sum_{i = 1}^{2011} a_i^2.$ The final Answer is -1941

 \begin{align} a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{2011} - \sum_{i = 1}^{2011} a_i^2 &= a_{2012} + 1 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - \sum_{i = 6}^{2011} (a_{i + 1} - a_i + 1) \\ &= a_{2012} + 1 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - (a_{2012} - a_6 + 2006) \\
 &= a_6 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - 2005 \\ &= 119 - (1^2 + 2^2 + 3^2 + 4^2 + 5^2) - 2005 \\ &= \boxed{-1941}. \end{align}

fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = i"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. i > 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = (prod a {1..i - 1}) - 1"
shows  "(prod a {1..2011}) - (sum (\<lambda>i. a i ^ 2) {1..2011}) = -1941"

What is the difference between the product of $a(i)$ for $1 \leq i \leq 2011$ and the sum of the squares of $a(i)$ over the same range? The final answer is $-1941$.

\[a_i = a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1} - 1\]for $i > 5.$  Evaluate $a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{2011} - \sum_{i = 1}^{2011} a_i^2.$ The final Answer is -1941

 \begin{align} a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{2011} - \sum_{i = 1}^{2011} a_i^2 &= a_{2012} + 1 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - \sum_{i = 6}^{2011} (a_{i + 1} - a_i + 1) \\ &= a_{2012} + 1 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - (a_{2012} - a_6 + 2006) \\

fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = i"

For all $i$ greater than 5, $a_i$ is the product of all previous terms of the sequence subtracted by 1. What is the difference between the product of the first 2011 terms of the sequence and the sum of the squares of these terms? The final answer is -1941.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int" and f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = i"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i > 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = prod a {1..i-1} - 1"
and h2 : "f i = a i powr 2"
shows  "prod a {1..2011} - sum f {1..2011} = -1941"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A sequence of integers is defined as follows: $a_i = i$ for $1 \le i \le 5,$ and
\[a_i = a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1} - 1\]for $i > 5.$  Evaluate $a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{2011} - \sum_{i = 1}^{2011} a_i^2.$ The final Answer is -1941
 ### Proof
 For $i \ge 6,$ $a_i = a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1} - 1.$  So \begin{align} a_{i + 1} &= a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_i - 1 \\ &= (a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1}) a_i - 1 \\ &= (a_i + 1) a_i - 1 \\ &= a_i^2 + a_i - 1. \end{align}Then $a_i^2 = a_{i + 1} - a_i + 1,$ so
 \begin{align} a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{2011} - \sum_{i = 1}^{2011} a_i^2 &= a_{2012} + 1 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - \sum_{i = 6}^{2011} (a_{i + 1} - a_i + 1) \\ &= a_{2012} + 1 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - (a_{2012} - a_6 + 2006) \\
 &= a_6 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - 2005 \\ &= 119 - (1^2 + 2^2 + 3^2 + 4^2 + 5^2) - 2005 \\ &= \boxed{-1941}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int" and f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = i"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i > 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = prod a {1..i-1} - 1"
and h2 : "f i = a i powr 2"
shows  "prod a {1..2011} - sum f {1..2011} = -1941"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: For a function $a(i)$, when $i$ is between 1 and 5, inclusive, $a(i)$ is equal to $i$. For $i$ greater than 5, $a(i)$ equals the product of $a$ for all values between 1 and $i-1$, minus 1. Another function, $f(i)$, is defined as the square of $a(i)$. Find the difference between the product of $a$ for all values from 1 to 2011 and the sum of $f$ for all values from 1 to 2011. The final answer is $-1941$.

fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = i"

1) For any integer $i$ between 1 and 5 (inclusive), $a(i) = i$.

What is the difference between the product of $a(i)$ for $i$ from 1 to 2011 and the sum of the squares of $a(i)$ for $i$ from 1 to 2011? The final answer is $-1941$.

theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int" and i :: int
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = i"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i > 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = (prod a {1..i - 1}) - 1"
shows  "prod a {1..2011} - (\<Sum>i = 1..2011. a i powr 2) = -1941"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Define a function $a(i)$ such that for all $i$ between 1 and 5 (inclusive), $a(i)=i$. For all $i$ greater than 5, $a(i)$ is the product of $a(1)$ through $a(i-1)$ minus 1. What is the difference between the product of $a(i)$ from $i=1$ to $i=2011$ and the sum of $a(i)^2$ from $i=1$ to $i=2011$? The final answer is $-1941$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and seq_sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and seq_prod :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = i"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i > 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = seq_prod (i - 1) - 1"
and h2 : "seq_sum n = (\<Sum>i=1..n. (a i)\<^sup>2)"
and h3 : "seq_prod n = (\<Prod>i=1..n. a i)"
shows  "seq_prod 2011 - seq_sum 2011 = -1941"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A sequence of integers is defined as follows: $a_i = i$ for $1 \le i \le 5,$ and
\[a_i = a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1} - 1\]for $i > 5.$  Evaluate $a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{2011} - \sum_{i = 1}^{2011} a_i^2.$ The final Answer is -1941
 ### Proof
 For $i \ge 6,$ $a_i = a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1} - 1.$  So \begin{align} a_{i + 1} &= a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_i - 1 \\ &= (a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{i - 1}) a_i - 1 \\ &= (a_i + 1) a_i - 1 \\ &= a_i^2 + a_i - 1. \end{align}Then $a_i^2 = a_{i + 1} - a_i + 1,$ so
 \begin{align} a_1 a_2 \dotsm a_{2011} - \sum_{i = 1}^{2011} a_i^2 &= a_{2012} + 1 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - \sum_{i = 6}^{2011} (a_{i + 1} - a_i + 1) \\ &= a_{2012} + 1 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - (a_{2012} - a_6 + 2006) \\
 &= a_6 - (a_1^2 + a_2^2 + a_3^2 + a_4^2 + a_5^2) - 2005 \\ &= 119 - (1^2 + 2^2 + 3^2 + 4^2 + 5^2) - 2005 \\ &= \boxed{-1941}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and seq_sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and seq_prod :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = i"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i > 5 \<longrightarrow> a i = seq_prod (i - 1) - 1"
and h2 : "seq_sum n = (\<Sum>i=1..n. (a i)\<^sup>2)"
and h3 : "seq_prod n = (\<Prod>i=1..n. a i)"
shows  "seq_prod 2011 - seq_sum 2011 = -1941"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A sequence $a$ is defined such that $a(i) = i$ for $1 \leq i \leq 5$, and $a(i) = seq\_prod(i - 1) - 1$ for $i > 5$. Here, $seq\_sum(n)$ is the sum of squares of the first $n$ terms of the sequence $a$, and $seq\_prod(n)$ is the product of the first $n$ terms of the sequence $a$. Find the value of $seq\_prod(2011) - seq\_sum(2011)$. The final answer is $-1941$.
